summary: This is a reply memorandum filed by the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) in a FOIA lawsuit brought by The New York Times Company. The BOP argues its withholdings of records related to Jeffrey Epstein's death and incarceration are proper under various FOIA exemptions (7(A), 6, 7(C), 5, 7(E), 7(F)), citing interference with pending criminal prosecutions (United States v. Tartaglione and United States v. Noel) and privacy interests. This is a legal memorandum filed by the government (likely the Department of Justice) in opposition to a FOIA request concerning Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death. The document argues for the proper withholding of records under various FOIA exemptions (7(A), 6, 7(C), 5, 7(E)), citing ongoing criminal proceedings, privacy interests of Epstein's family and third parties, and the protection of law enforcement techniques and internal deliberations. This document is page 24-25 of a court filing from the U.S. Department of Justice defending the Bureau of Prisons' use of FOIA Exemption 7(E) to withhold investigatory records related to Jeffrey Epstein's suicide. It argues that releasing specific investigatory techniques used in response to Epstein's suicide attempt and death would compromise their effectiveness in federal prisons.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Acting United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, whose office is representing the defendant (BOP) in this FOIA case.

persons.name: Russell Capone
persons.role: Counsel to the Acting United States Attorney / Supervising Prosecutor
persons.context: Submitted declarations explaining how disclosure of withheld records could interfere with the pending criminal prosecutions of Tartaglione and Noel.

persons.name: Kara Christenson
persons.context: Submitted declarations on behalf of the Bureau of Prisons detailing the FOIA review process, productions, and bases for withholdings.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the FOIA request; the document concerns records related to his incarceration, apparent suicide attempt, and death by suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

persons.name: Nicole McFarland
persons.context: Submitted a supplemental declaration correcting and clarifying information related to the FOIA review.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: A defendant in the criminal case 'United States v. Noel' (No. 19-cr-830). The government argues that disclosing records related to Epstein would interfere with this ongoing prosecution.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: Named as a defendant in a pending federal criminal prosecution (United States v. Noel) mentioned as a reason for withholding records under Exemption 7(A).

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: A defendant in the criminal case 'United States v. Noel' (No. 19-cr-830). The document references this case to justify withholding records under Exemption 7(A) due to potential interference with the prosecution.

persons.name: Epstein's brother
persons.context: Identified as having a privacy interest in preventing the public release of details and images related to Jeffrey Epstein's death, as argued by the government under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7(C).

persons.name: Capone
persons.context: Author of a declaration (Capone Decl.) cited by the government to explain how public disclosure of records could interfere with the criminal prosecution in 'United States v. Noel' by influencing witnesses and jury selection.

persons.name: Christenson
persons.context: Author of a declaration (Christenson Decl.) cited by the government to explain the deliberative nature of certain documents and the harm from their disclosure under FOIA Exemption 5.

persons.name: Torres
persons.context: Judge in the 'Noel' criminal case. The government references a decision by Judge Torres that it argues cuts against the FOIA plaintiff's position.

connections.description: Capone is Counsel to the Acting United States Attorney (Strauss) and a supervising prosecutor in her office.
Noel is a defendant in a prosecution related to Epstein's death; records about Epstein's incarceration are potential evidence in her case.
Thomas is a co-defendant with Noel in a prosecution related to Epstein's death.
The government asserts that Epstein's brother has a recognized privacy interest in preventing the public release of details and images of his brother's death.
Both are defendants in the same criminal case, United States v. Noel (No. 19-cr-830).
The document references third-party individuals who called, visited, or transferred funds to Epstein while he was incarcerated. The government argues for protecting their identities.

events.title: Epstein's Apparent Suicide Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein had an apparent suicide attempt while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: BOP Files Motion for Summary Judgment
events.description: The Bureau of Prisons filed its opening brief in support of its motion for summary judgment in this FOIA case.

events.title: BOP Produces Additional Records
events.description: BOP produced 77 additional pages of records to The New York Times, with partial redactions.

events.title: BOP Produces More Records
events.description: BOP produced 351 additional pages of records to The New York Times, with partial redactions.

events.title: BOP Produces Returned Records
events.description: BOP produced 190 pages of records from materials returned by the OIG, with 387 pages withheld in full.

events.title: Epstein's apparent suicide attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein attempted suicide while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). This event triggered internal BOP deliberations and investigations.

events.title: Epstein's suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide (hanging) in his cell at the MCC. This event is the subject of the FOIA request and subsequent BOP investigations.

events.title: Disclosure in Noel case
events.description: The government disclosed materials related to the FOIA request to defendants in the 'United States v. Noel' case under a protective order, which the government argues is distinct from public FOIA disclosure.

events.title: Epstein suicide investigation techniques withheld
events.description: The Bureau of Prisons is withholding specific investigatory techniques and procedures deployed in response to Jeffrey Epstein's suicide attempt and suicide under FOIA Exemption 7(E).

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
86 Chambers Street, Third Floor, New York, New York 10007
Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) - The federal jail in New York where Jeffrey Epstein was incarcerated and died.
Southern District of New York (S.D.N.Y.) - The federal court district where the criminal case 'United States v. Noel' and the FOIA lawsuit are pending.
keyFacts: The BOP is withholding records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death under FOIA Exemption 7(A), arguing disclosure could interfere with two pending federal criminal prosecutions: United States v. Tartaglione (a death penalty case) and United States v. Noel.
Withheld records include potential trial exhibits, information about expected witnesses, and documents prepared by potential witnesses for the Noel prosecution.
The BOP also cites privacy interests (Exemptions 6 & 7(C)) to protect images of Epstein's body, details of his suicide, and the names of his associates.
The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General (OIG) returned records to BOP from its investigation into Epstein's death, which BOP then reviewed for FOIA production.

The parties have resolved the issue of the adequacy of BOP's search by agreement, and plaintiff has agreed not to challenge certain withholdings under Exemptions 7(E) and 7(F) related to MCC security and employee safety.
The government is actively opposing a FOIA request for records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death, citing multiple exemptions to prevent disclosure.
A key argument is that public release of the records would interfere with the ongoing criminal prosecution in 'United States v. Noel' (Exemption 7(A)).
The government asserts a privacy interest for Epstein's brother in preventing the release of details and images of Epstein's death (Exemptions 6 and 7(C)).

The identities of third parties (visitors, callers, fund transferors) who interacted with Epstein in prison are being withheld to protect their privacy, even if some associations are publicly speculated.

Internal BOP documents concerning suicide prevention measures, housing decisions for Epstein, and investigative techniques are withheld as pre-decisional deliberations and protected law enforcement procedures (Exemptions 5 and 7(E)).
The Bureau of Prisons is withholding investigatory records related to Jeffrey Epstein's suicide under FOIA Exemption 7(E), claiming disclosure would compromise their effectiveness.

Withheld information includes STG (Security Threat Group) designations, emergency response steps in the Special Housing Unit, investigatory sources and steps at the MCC, After Action Review team procedures, and evidence storage details.
The government argues these specific investigatory techniques are not the same as publicly known suicide prevention techniques like 'double-ceiling'.
The filing is dated January 15, 2021, and argues for granting the government's motion for summary judgment in the FOIA case.
